title: Long-term Trajectories of Crime in the UK
abstractText:
• In what ways are changes in economic and social policies associated with changes in crime rates anxieties about crime?
  • How do shifts in social values affect national-level experiences and beliefs about crime and appropriate responses to it (such as support for punitiveness)?
  • What have been the long-term consequences of neo-liberal and neo-conservative social and economic policies for the UK's criminal justice system and crime?
  • In what ways do changes in social and economic circumstances lead to changes in crime rates 'downstream'?
  • Conversely, in what ways do changes in crime rates affect social and economic policies?.
  • Which social economic groups are most affected with regards to experiences of crime? What lessons can be learnt for the future?

Our aim is to understand the long-term trajectory of crime alongside political, social and economic developments (and in so doing to develop an approach for making such assessments which could also be used by other researchers). Using time series modelling, the project will chart these trends generally as well as exploring the impact of the growing existence and tolerance of economic inequalities since the 1970s on a range of key processes related to crime (such as, for example, popular sentiments towards the treatment of offenders).
